      • makeFilenameSafe

        public static java.lang.String makeFilenameSafe(java.lang.String string,
                                java.lang.String replace)
        Removes unsafe filename characters from the given string.
        Parameters:
        string - the string to make filename safe
        replace - what you want bad characters to be replaced with (note, if you give an invalid character for this parameter, it will be automatically replaced with an empty string, the same applies if null is given).
        Returns:
        the string with characters replaced

      • getFileBytes

        public static byte[] getFileBytes(java.io.File file)
                           throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                                  java.io.IOException,
                                  java.lang.Exception
        Reads the given bytes into an array. The bytes must not exceed the array size limit of Integer.MAX_VALUE (which is 2^31 -1). This means you can only use this method with files under 2 gigabytes
        Parameters:
        file -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - when trying to get the file
        java.io.IOException - when trying to read the file
        java.lang.Exception - when trying to read a file too big for a byte[]

      • zipFiles

        public static void zipFiles(java.io.File destination,
            java.io.File... files)
                     throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                            java.io.IOException,
                            java.lang.Exception
        This uses the java.util.zip library to zip the given files to the given destination. It creates a FileOutputStream for the given destination, then calls writeZipInToOut(fileOutput, files); The benchmark for this method has proven to be slightly slower than the zipFiles(HelperFile...) method, but this one can handle any file size while the other is limited to Integer.MAX_VALUE (2 GB sized files)
        Parameters:
        destination -
        files -
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException
        java.io.IOException
        java.lang.Exception - if the files are bigger than Integer.MAX_VALUE (2 GB)

      • zipFiles

        public static byte[] zipFiles(HelperFile... files)
                       throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                              java.io.IOException
        This uses the java.util.zip library to zip the given HelperFiles and return a byte array of the zip file. Creates a ByteArrayOutputStream, calls writeZipInToOut(byteOutput, files); and returns byteOutput.toByteArray()
        Parameters:
        files -
        Returns:
        byte[] of the zip file of the given files
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException
        java.io.IOException

      • replaceInFile

        public static boolean replaceInFile(java.io.File file,
                    java.lang.String find,
                    java.lang.String replace)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Replaces the given find with the given replace in the given file. Reads the file to a string, replaces the find with the replace in the string and prints the new string on top of the original file.
        Parameters:
        file - the file to conduct the find/replace on
        find - the find to replace
        replace - the text to replace the find with
        Returns:
        whether anything was different in the replace call. It does not print over the original file if nothing is different
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • replaceInAllFiles

        public static java.util.List<java.io.File>[] replaceInAllFiles(java.io.File topDirectory,
                                               int sublevels,
                                               java.lang.String find,
                                               java.lang.String replace,
                                               java.lang.String... extension)
        Replaces the given find with the given replace in all the files under the given directory of the given file extension(s). If the file extension is null (or omitted), it will ignore the file extension and apply to all files regardless of their extension. Calls replaceInFile(file, find, replace) on each of the files. Skips any files which throw IO exceptions and adds it to the list which is returned. You can call sendReplaceInAllFilesToPrinter(List[]) on the returned array and it will send information to the Printer
        Parameters:
        topDirectory - the topDirectory to find the files in
        sublevels - determines how many subdirectories to go before it stops adding files. Give 0 to get files only in the given directory
        find - the text to be replaced by the given replace
        replace - the text to replace the given find with
        extension - the any-number of extensions to apply the find/replace to. Omit for any type
        Returns:
        An array of Lists of Files: arry[0] = files which applied and were successful in the find/replace operation; arry[1] = files which may have been successful, but there would have been no change to the file during the find/replace operation so the file was not overwritten; arry[2] = files which threw an IOException for any reason.

      • getReplaceInAllFilesAsString

        public static java.lang.String getReplaceInAllFilesAsString(java.util.List<java.io.File>[] replaced)
        This is helpful just for seeing a report of a call to replaceInAllFiles().
        Parameters:
        replaced - an array of lists of files from replaceInAllFiles()
        Returns:
        String representation of the replaced lists
        See Also:
        replaceInAllFiles(), sendReplaceInAllFilesToPrinter()

      • sendReplaceInAllFilesToPrinter

        public static void sendReplaceInAllFilesToPrinter(java.util.List<java.io.File>[] replaced)
        Prints the given list array of files. It's pretty much only useful for the return on the replaceInAllFiles method. NOTE: Uses PrinterHelper
        Parameters:
        replaced -
        See Also:
        replaceInAllFiles(), getReplaceInAllFilesAsString()

      • getAllFiles

        public static java.util.List<java.io.File> getAllFiles(java.io.File file,
                                       int subdirectories,
                                       java.lang.String... extension)
        Gets all the files under the given file (not including the given file).
        Parameters:
        file - the file to get files under
        subdirectories - determines how many subdirectories to go before it stops adding files. Give 0 to get files only in the given directory (or just call getDirectoryFiles(file, extension) instead). If you want to get all files in all subdirectories, give anything less than -2. Be careful though, if it's a high parent directory, this might take a while to return :)
        extension - the extension(s) to add to the returned list. If null or omitted will add all files to the returned list (not including directories)
        Returns:

      • getDirectoryFiles

        public static java.util.List<java.io.File> getDirectoryFiles(java.io.File directory,
                                             java.lang.String... extension)
        Gets files in the given directory.
        Parameters:
        directory - the directory to search for files in.
        extension - the text the file should end with to be added to the returned list
        Returns:
        a list of the files in the directory

      • print

        public static void print(java.io.File destination,
         java.lang.String string)
                  throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
        Prints the given file string to the file destination. This same operation could be done by calling saveBytes(string.getBytes(), destination). When benchmarking, this method was found to be only a few milliseconds faster.
        Parameters:
        destination -
        string -
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException
